questions.question_text: What are two functions of the Service Engines in NSX Advanced Load Balancer? (Choose two.)

choices.A: It collects real-time analytics from application traffic flows.
choices.B: It stores the configuration and policies related to load-balancing services.
choices.C: It deploys web servers to perform load-balancing operations.
choices.E: It provides a user interface to perform configuration and management tasks.

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: AD
The answer is A and D

The Service Engines

The NSX Advanced Load Balancer Service Engines (SEs) are the data-plane component. SEs collect real-time application analytics from traffic flows between end users and applications. The SEs are high-performance data-plane entities which perform the actual load balancing (LB) and web application firewall (WAF) functions. All configurations for a given SE are managed by the respective Controller Cluster.

Selected Answer: AD
Reference: https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-NSX-Advanced-Load-Balancer/22.1/Administration_Guide/GUID-84139C37-0129-40A7-A7AB-5A93E1F65B6D.html
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-NSX-T-Data-Center/3.2/administration/GUID-C0CAEFB2-55B9-4229-8083-BE18448C3944.html?hWord=N4IghgNiBcIDIHYAEBBAxmgpgZ20gCgE4D2AZgJYSYgC+QA

Selected Answer: D
Reference: https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-NSX-T-Data-Center/3.2/administration/GUID-C5CD87FD-8095-49F3-97CE-E606AB89162E.html

Selected Answer: D
Destination

questions.question_text: Which field in a Tier-1 Gateway Firewall would be used to allow access for a collection of trustworthy web sites?

choices.D:
- show logical-routers
- get vrf
- show ip route bgp
choices.B:
- set vrf
- show logical-routers
- show bgp
choices.C:
- get gateways
- vrf
- get bgp neighbor
choices.A:
- enable
- get vrf
- show bgp neighbor

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: C
C is good answer.

We can see another question in this bundle with a clear example...

Selected Answer: C
C is correct although the documentation tends to only talk about "get logical-routers" as the command. 

"get gateways stats" is a valid command in 4.x but not well documented
None are right. get gateways is not a valid command. it should be get logical-routers

Selected Answer: C
C is the answer.

Selected Answer: C
Tested in CLI 
C is the answer

Selected Answer: D
Reference: https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-NSX/4.1/administration/GUID-9554C339-69DE-4C97-8392-DCCA67682B35.html

C
This can be validated on the cli

questions.question_text:
An administrator wants to validate the BGP connection status between the Tier-0 Gateway and the upstream physical router.

What sequence of commands could be used to check this status on NSX Edge node?
What are two supported host switch modes? (Choose two.)

discussion.content:
Selected Answer: CD
Correct, CD.

Here's some better documentation on that:
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-NSX-T-Data-Center/3.2/administration/GUID-A3674EA2-F368-4A53-9078-0694F76624F4.html

Selected Answer: CD
C & D are correct.

Selected Answer: CD
Reference:
https://nsx.techzone.vmware.com/resource/nsx-reference-design-guide#a-31-the-nsx-virtual-switch

BD are the good answers for me.

Saw in the ICM 4.0 p.595.

The following L2 VPN clients are recommended: 
1. NSX Managed NSX Edge in a separate NSX Managed environment. 
• Overlay and VLAN segments can be extended.
2. Autonomous Edge: 
• Enables L2 VPN access from a non-a NSX environment to NSX environments. 
• Deployed by using an OVF file on a host that is not managed by NSX. 
• Only VLAN segments can be extended.

Selected Answer: BD
B and D 
https://blogs.vmware.com/vmware-japan/2022/06/vmc-nsx-autonomous-edge.html

Selected Answer: BD
B and D 
https://docs.vmware.com/en/VMware-NSX/4.0/administration/GUID-86C8D6BB-F185-46DC-828C-1E1876B854E8.html
must be an NSX Edge either managed or unmanaged.

I think B & D are good.
ICM 9-104

Selected Answer: BC
The L2 VPN service support is provided in the following deployment scenarios. 
• Between an NSX-T Data Center L2 VPN server and an L2 VPN client hosted on an NSX Edge that is managed in an NSX Data Center for vSphere environment. A managed L2 VPN client supports both VLANs and VNIs.
• Between an NSX-T Data Center L2 VPN server and an L2 VPN client hosted on a standalone or unmanaged NSX Edge. An unmanaged L2 VPN client supports VLANs only.
• Between an NSX-T Data Center L2 VPN server and an L2 VPN client hosted on an autonomous NSX Edge. An autonomous L2 VPN client supports VLANs only.

questions.question_text: Which two are supported by L2 VPN clients? (Choose two.)
